document.masterDocTitle: A revision of the species of the pseudoscorpion subgenus Chthonius (Ephippiochthonius) (Arachnida, Pseudoscorpiones, Chthoniidae) from Italy and neighbouring areas

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A revision of the species of the pseudoscorpion subgenus Chthonius (Ephippiochthonius) (Arachnida, Pseudoscorpiones, Chthoniidae) from Italy and neighbouring areas

subSubSection.paragraph:
Chthonius (Ephippiochthonius) austriacus nanus Beier 1953 c: 105
, fig. 1 (in part, 3 only).

Chthonius (E.) elbanus
Beier 1963 b: 151 , fig. 2 (n. syn.) .

Chthonius (E.) tetrachelatus
(not Preyssler, 1790 ): Lazzeroni 1969 b: 395 (misidentification, in part).

Chthonius (E.) elbanus
(not Beier, 1963 ): Lazzeroni 1970 : 103 ; Gardini 1975 : 387 , fig. 1 ; Callaini 1979 b: 345 , figs Ic–d; Callaini 1980 : 227 ; Callaini 1981 : 308 ; Callaini 1983 a: 149 ; Callaini 1983 b: 412 ; Callaini 1984 : 130 , figs IIA–D; Gardini et al. 1997 : 221 ; Gardini 2004 : 127 ; Gardini 2008 a: 6 ; Gardini 2008 b: 631 .

Chthonius (Ephippiochthonius) nanus : Gardini 1980 c: 264
, figs 8–15 .

Chthonius (Ephippiochthonius) gibbus
(not Beier, 1953 ): Gardini et al. 1997 : 221 (misidentification, in part).

Chthonius ( Ephippiochthonius )
sp. prope
elbanus : Gardini 2008 b: 631
(misidentification).

Type locality:
Italy , Liguria, Genoa Prov., Valbrevenna, Tann-a da Reixe 132 Li/GE ( 44 ° 32 ’ 47 ʺN 9 °05’ 39 ʺE).
Distribution. Switzerland , mainland Italy , Sicily, Sardinia, Corsica , Morocco (?).

Diagnosis ( Ƥ ). An eyed epigean
Chthonius ( Ephippiochthonius )
that differs from other species of the
C. fuscimanus
group in the following combination of characters: movable cheliceral finger with isolated subapical tooth ( di ) level with spinneret; both sexes with spinneret; carapace without epistome; pedipalpal hand (in lateral view) without a rounded hump distad of trichobothria ib-isb , weakly depressed at level of ib-isb ; fixed and movable chelal fingers respectively with 9–12 and 5–7 triangular teeth; fixed chelal finger at level of est-it with 5 teeth occupying 0.1 mm (distance between successive apices 0.026–0.031 mm ); proximal half of movable chelal finger with straight, thick marginal lamina; length of chela 0.52–0.65 ( 3 ), 0.56–0.73 (Ƥ), length of movable chelal finger 0.29–0.37 ( 3 ), 0.31–0.40 (Ƥ); chela 4.6–5.9 ( 3 ) 4.1 –5.0 (Ƥ) times as long as deep; ratio of pedipalpal femur/ carapace 1.15–1.3 ( 3 Ƥ).

Type material examined.
ITALY— Liguria: Genoa Prov. — Lectotype 3 of
C. nanus

n. sp. Ƥ Type det. Beier” “Chiessi (Elba), macchia Lecci, foglie marce e terriccio.

Valle Bianchi” (MBCG).

Description of adults ( Ƥ ). Integument pigmented, carapace, tergites, chelicerae and pedipalps brown; hispid granulation on lateral surface of carapace, on cheliceral palm, on ventrodistal surface of chelal hand and on the base of movable chelal finger. Carapace 1.0– 1.1 , subquadrate; anterior margin (fig. 163–164 ) strongly dentate between median macrosetae, without epistome, sometimes weakly prominent; ocular area as in fig. 165 , anterior eyes with convex lens (diameter 0.028–0.037 mm ), posterior eyes reduced to a smooth cuticular area, all eyes with tapetum; distance from anterior eyes to anterior margin of carapace 0.02–0.03 mm ; chaetotaxy mm 4mm : 6 : 4 : 2 : 2 ( 18 ), macrosetae thick; length of anteromedian macrosetae 0.07–0.09 mm . Chaetotaxy tergites
I– X 4
: 4 : 4 : 4 : 6 : 6 : 6 : 6 : 6 : 4 . Chaetotaxy sternites
II–X 10
:( 3 ) 8 ( 3 ):( 2 ) 7 ( 2 ): 8 : 6 : 6 : 6 : 6 : 7 ; sternite II rarely with 9 or 11 setae, st. III rarely with ( 3 ) 6–7 ( 3 ) setae, st. IV rarely with ( 2 ) 6 ( 2 ) setae; genital opening of males flanked by 6–7 (rarely 5 or 8 ) setae on each side. Chelicerae (figs 166–167 ) 1.9–2.1 times as long as broad, palm with 6 setae and 2 microsetae laterally; fixed finger with 4–6 teeth proximally reduced in size and 5–7 proximal microtubercles; movable finger with a large isolated subapical tooth ( di ) at level with the spinneret, 3–5 teeth (the first distal two teeth fused together and prominent) and 3–4 proximal tubercles; gl ratio 0.53–0.60 ; spinneret prominent and apically rounded in both sexes; rallum with 11 blades; serrulae interior and exterior respectively with 12 and 14 blades. Coxal setae: pedipalp 5 (including 2 on manducatory process),
I 3
+ 3 marginal microsetae,
II 4
,
III 5
,
IV 6
; coxa II with 5–12 (mostly 5–7 ) coxal spines, coxa III with 2–5 (mostly 3–4 ) coxal spines; intercoxal tubercle bisetose. Pedipalp: femur 5.1 –6.0 ( 3 ), 4.8–5.7 (Ƥ) times as long as broad; chela (figs 168–170 ) 4.6–5.9 ( 3 ), 4.1 – 5.0 (Ƥ) times as long as deep; hand of chela 2.1–2.5 ( 3 ), 1.8–2.4 (Ƥ) times as long as deep, weakly depressed at level of ib-isb ; fixed chelal finger with 10–13 large triangular teeth with dental canals: the first 1–2 proximal teeth with tip rounded, the others weakly reclined, with pointed tip, rarely with one subdistal very small tooth; base of fixed finger with 5–10 microtubercles; tip of fixed finger with a modified accessory tooth ( td ) on antiaxial face; fixed chelal finger at level of est-it with 5 teeth occupying 0.1 mm (distance between successive apices 0.026– 0.031 mm ); distal half of movable chelal finger with 5–7 upright, triangular teeth with dental canals, rarely with one subdistal very small tooth; proximal half of movable chelal finger with thick, straight or weakly undulated marginal lamina and few microtubercles at level of sb ; coupled sensilla pc halfway between b and sb , mostly nearer sb (rarely distad of sb ); trichobothria as in figs 169–170 , eb-esb-ist mostly placed in a straight line; basal apodeme of movable finger strongly sclerotized, rectangular, straight or bent, apically truncated and crenellated; ratio of movable finger/hand of chela 1.2–1.4 ( 3 ), 1.1–1.3 (Ƥ); ratio of pedipalpal femur/movable finger 1.2–1.3 (rarely 1.4 ) ( 3 Ƥ); ratio of pedipalpal femur/carapace 1.15–1.3 ( 3 Ƥ).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 163–168 .
Chthonius (E.) nanus
Beier, 1953 (Liguria, Isola di Rovegno). 163, male, anterior margin of carapace; 164, female, id.; 165, male, anterolateral portion of carapace; 166, id., right chelicera; 167, female, id.; 168, male, tip of fixed chelal finger, dorsal view.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Description of tritonymph. Integument with weak pigmentation and hispid granulation, less marked than in adults. Carapace 1.0 times longer than broad, anterior margin and eyes as in adults; chaetotaxy m 4m : 6 : 4 : 2 : 2 ( 18 ), length of anteromedian macrosetae 0.055 mm . Chaetotaxy of tergites as in adults. Chaetotaxy of sternites
II–X 5
:( 2 ) 6 ( 2 ):( 1 ) 6 ( 1 ): 8 : 6 : 6 : 6 : 6 : 7 . Chelicerae 2.0 times as long as broad, palm with 5 setae and 1 lateral microseta; fixed finger with 4 teeth, movable finger with an isolated subapical tooth ( di ) and 3–4 contiguous teeth; gl ratio 0.60 . Pedipalp: femur 4.4 –5.0 times as long as broad; chela 4.5–5.1 times as long as deep; hand of chela 2.0– 2.2 times as long as deep; fixed finger with 10–11 large, triangular teeth, the first proximal one apically rounded; base of fixed finger with few microtubercles; tip of fixed finger with a modified accessory tooth ( td ) on antiaxial face; distal half of movable chelal finger with 6–7 triangular teeth (rarely with one very small subdistal tooth), proximal half with thick marginal lamina weakly undulated; base of movable finger with few microtubercles; coupled sensilla pc a little distad of b ; ratio of movable finger/hand of chela 1.2–1.3 ; ratio of pedipalpal femur/movable finger 1.2 ; ratio of pedipalpal femur/carapace 1.0– 1.1 .

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 169–170 .
Chthonius (E.) nanus
Beier, 1953 (Liguria, Isola di Rovegno). 169, male, right chela, lateral view; 170, female, id. (Scale bar 0.1 mm).

subSubSection.paragraph: Measurements (in mm). Carapace 0.27–0.28 × 0.26–0.27 ( 0.22–0.24 anteriorly). Chelicerae 0.20 × 0.10 , movable finger length 0.095 . Pedipalp: femur 0.265–0.30 × 0.057–0.06 ; chela 0.41–0.46 × 0.085–0.095 ; hand length 0.17–0.20 ; movable finger length 0.22–0.25 .

Remarks. Beier ( 1953 c) described
Chthonius (E.) austriacus nanus
from a male and a female from the cave Tann-a da Reixe near Torriglia (Genoa Prov.) and subsequently (Beier 1963 a) raised it to specific status. Gardini ( 1980 c) examined the types of
C. nanus
and found that they belong to two different species. The male type was selected as the lectotype (“ holotype ” in Gardini 1980 c) and the female paralectotype was identified as C. cfr.
gibbus
(see Remarks under
C. tyrrhenicus
).

Beier ( 1963 b) described
Chthonius (E.) elbanus
from a single female from Chiessi (Elba Island) and compared it with
C. gibbus
,
C. siculus
and
C. pyrenaicus (Beier, 1934 )
. Later authors have recorded
C. elbanus
from many, chiefly Italian, localities (Gardini 2000 , Harvey 2011 ).

Comparison between the male lectotype of
C. nanus
and the female holotype of
C. elbanus
, together with the examination of the above listed material, reveals that differences between the two are only due to sexual dimorphism, hence
Chthonius
( E. )
elbanus Beier, 1963
is here considered a junior subjective synonym of C. ( E. )
nanus Beier, 1953
( n. syn. ).

Among the species of the
Chthonius fuscimanus
group,
C. nanus
is related to
C. tyrrhenicus
, an epigean species common and widespread over a large portion of the same geographical area, to
C. intemelius
from western Liguria and to
C. aeneae
from eastern Liguria.
C. nanus
differs from
C. tyrrhenicus
chiefly in the shape of pedipalpal hand (with a more rectangular profile in
C. nanus
, with a more square profile in
C. tyrrhenicus
) and the larger size (length of chela 0.52–0.65 ( 3 ) 0.56–0.73 (Ƥ) mm in
C. nanus
, 0.435–0.54 ( 3 ) 0.47–0.60 (Ƥ) mm in
C. tyrrhenicus
). Many syntopic occurrences of
C. nanus
and
C. tyrrhenicus
have been detected in Liguria (Genoa and Savona Provinces: see Material examined).

For comparisons between
C. nanus
,
C. aeneae
and
C. intemelius
see Remarks under the latter two species.

The above description of
C. nanus
corresponds to those published by Gardini ( 1975 ) and Callaini (1979, 1984), except that only some specimens from Sardinia (Oddastru and Oliena) and Corsica (Oletta) (Callaini 1984 ) are slightly smaller dimensions than those reported here. Three specimens ( 1 3 2 Ƥ) from, respectively, three islets of NE Sardinia (Is. Li Nibani 1 , Is. delle Rocche, Is. Soffi), previously referred to
Chthonius
sp. prope
elbanus
by Gardini ( 2008 b), are now considered conspecific with
C. nanus
, in spite of being smaller than normal (length of chela 0.46–0.48 mm ); the dimensions given in the description above do not take these specimens into account.

Many Italian records of
C. nanus
reported by Gardini ( 2000 ) (as
C. elbanus
) remain to be verified.
